awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Comprehensive Characterization of Atmospheric Organic Carbon over Multiple Generations of Oxidation
awd_abstract_narration:
This project supports laboratory studies of the chemical evolution of organic carbon in the atmosphere.  Research is ongoing to investigate how key properties of organic compounds change as they undergo multiple generations of atmospheric aging.  This effort will provide significant insight into the distribution of carbon across species and into the formation of organic aerosol in the atmosphere.  This research will help improve current models of air quality and climate change.

The specific scientific objectives of this project are as follows: (1) The development of laboratory approaches and capabilities for chemically characterizing all carbon within a laboratory aging context, using a range of speciated and ensemble techniques; and (2) Application of these approaches to key atmospheric aging systems in order to track the evolution of organic carbon within both the gas and particle phases.  Recent advances in the characterization of atmospheric organic species, including traditionally difficult-to-measure species such as multifunctional oxidized VOCs (OVOCs) and semivolatile and intermediate-volatility organic compounds (S/IVOCs), enable carbon closure studies to be carried out in the laboratory for the first time.

por.por_cntn:
Organic (carbon-containing) compounds in the atmosphere are central to both air quality and global climate. The atmospheric oxidation of organic compounds can lead to the formation of harmful products such as ozone and particulate matter; these have negative influences on human health and also serve as climate forcers. However, our understanding of the formation of such pollutants is limited by the immense complexity of the oxidation process: the oxidation of atmospheric organic compounds can proceed via a large number of different reaction pathways, leading to the formation of a huge number of products, most of which will evolve over time. The aim of this project was to examine the formation of such products by examining these oxidation processes under controlled laboratory conditions. Different volatile organic compounds (VOCs) were oxidized by the hydroxyl (OH) radical in an environmental chamber, and a suite of analytical instruments (mostly mass spectrometers) was used to measure the reactants, intermediates, and products in real time. Much of the initial work involved developing approaches to combine measurements from multiple instruments (identifying both overlaps and gaps between them) and to calibrate instruments for compounds that are not readily available (or even fully characterized). By applying these approaches to out chamber datasets, we were able to achieve “carbon closure”, in which all (or nearly all) the reacted carbon was measured as products, for most VOCs studied. With this complete description of the reaction products, we were able to examine how key properties of the organic products species (such as molecular size, volatility, and oxidation state) evolve over time in the atmosphere, as well as compare measurements against predictions from state-of-the-art atmospheric chemistry models.
